comment-body: Institutions, business and governments need to be transparent in the ways they use AI, we need legislation and regulation to secure this
Global AI regulation needs to involve civil society, academia, industry and the open source community to get to the best possible outcome
Governments should consider public investment in, and development of, AI to steer applications towards generating long-term public benefit.
Decisions about how this tech is developed should not lie solely in the hands of private companies and their employees
Governance of AI must pay attention to its material dimensions e.g. its energy demands, or the creation of physical infrastructure
We should consider how to incentivize AI for common good (better democracy, less pollution, improved education) rather than cost-efficiency
AI could aid in discovering production/extraction efficiencies (of scarce resources) and also accelerate human-caused environmental damage
AI's advantages and weaknesses (Better memory, faster thinking,Heavy energy dependence) Should be communicated more clearly to the public.
The ability for frontier AI models to undermine democracy is an underaddressed problem.
We need a permanent global deliberative forum for the regulation of AI development.
Bias in training data is an area that needs to be urgently addresses to prevent the perpetuation of discrimination and cultural stereotypes
Greater priority should be awarded to educating the public on AI's societal impacts, including its incorporation into national curriculums
We need global standards in place to evaluate the environmental impact of AI technologies
We need to foster better education and awareness of generative AI, it’s potential benefits and it’s limitations/biases.
A business imperative (i.e., profits, growth) must not be the driving force of AI innovation
We should be very weary of AI models being trained on data previously generated by other AI models
Steps must be taken to ensure that future technological developments do not concentrate power in the hands of the state or private companies
AI should be embraced for the public good. Private entities controlling either need to be open source or governed by a public body
AI governance alone is not enough: it is necessary to critique both the state and capitalism, to understand how AI consolidates their power
Communities affected by use of AI tools must have a say in decisions about their development or adoption
AI regulatory bodies should be created to rapidly respond to novel less-than-existential AI alignment failures while legislation catches up.
Governments should clarify liability law, so that legal & financial liability for AI risk is distributed fairly along AI value chains.
Governments should introduce mandatory reporting requirements for foundation model developers, e.g. at the start or end of training runs.
The material costs of computing and AI (electricity, water, land, ...), and who gets to decide to spend those, are a key governance issue
AI may perpetuate not only cultural bias, but an ontology that is capitalist/extractive/zero-sum—embedding unsustainable mindsets is a risk
Global AI regulation needs to empower the open source community as without it, it will be very difficult to have the right checks in place
Future AI models have the potential to lower expertise barriers for crafting biological weapons, which poses a significant global threat
There needs to be a great shift towards funding/investing in AI interpretability research instead of raw capabilities as soon as possible.
We need more pragmatic and less moralistic discussion on how to democratize AI (e.g., public funding (access) and IP reforms(innovation))
Companies and institutions should be formally celebrated when they explicitly label interactions with them as AI or human-based
Should think about how AI may enable global coordination solutions, enabling major states/institutions to cooperate against other crises
Sovereign AI capacity is essential: it cannot just be private companies developing AI.
Democratisation of the development and deployment of AI is inherently limited if we do not also democratise the ownership of its production.
My work shows that the data used to train AI is the most important thing to focus on. We should regulate its use carefully.
An arms race for AI supremacy cannot be allowed
We must solve for a sustainable, adaptive, & effective global coordination mechanism
Short-term AI risks to economic and social inequalities are linked, and should be addressed together in ways that acknowledge intersections
We need multiple approaches to governing AI, Focus on one too much means privileging some aspects of society over others.
We must be careful not to conflate dangerous 'language hacking' potential of LLMs etc with the tremendous benefits of focussed AI tools.
We should think about many schools of moral philosophy when developing AI
AI alignment failures are better to happen sooner, with less powerful systems, than later, with more powerful systems.
AIs should consider the effect their decisions will have on human freedom & autonomy balanced against on peace, harmony, and safety.
Overreliance on AI may exacerbate a less skilled & less engaged citizenry
The way the media report on AI is driving a hype that is counter-productive to the broad objective of developing ethical frameworks.
I think the development of AI will relate heavily to the cultural shifts present in our phase in history w/ institutional trust.
Asking AI to seek truth may provide some safety, but we should also align AI with other values like having fun, freedom, and love.
Among the goals of an aligned AI superintelligence should be the material prosperity of all humans relatively equally.
Greater focus should be placed on tackling the near-term risks of AI (bias, misinformation, etc.) than the existential risks.
The epistemic risks of AI are a consequence of how our social structures enable and incentivise wealth accumulation
More attention should be paid to short-term AI risks related to economic inequality, relative to social inequality, than there is currently.
On their current development and release paradigm, LLMs are far more likely to pollute and degrade our information ecosystem than improve it
Societies need to be preemptive and design for mass unemployment linked to AI, rather than wait and react after people start suffering
The use of AI needs to be embraced within education systems to shift away from memorisation model to a critical and creative one
An agenda should ask how AI might supplement, but not replace us
AI development should be targeted at clearly demarcated contexts and the communities in those contexts involved in the development of the AI
More safety checks, peer review, and scrutiny from regulatory bodies, needs to happen before a Large singular AI training run even begins.
The creation of sentient AI should be avoided if non-sentient AI of identical capabilities are possible instead.
AI development should not be accelerated on the fear that China might get ahead of the US.
We need a single *international* approach to AI governance - national is not enough.
AI has the potential to create a more equitable world if approached critically & ethically. I'd like to see the ethics of AI advanced.
We need quality regulation that stops abuses and dangerous developments but is fast and does not prevent new ideas and innovation.
Love in the forms of connection, tolerance, caring, and compassion are central human values that should be encouraged in AI training.
AI's potential and pitfalls are overstated by AI 'experts'. The conversation about it shouldn't exclude opinions of everyone else
The US should establish a NIST or FDA-style federal agency to regulate the development and deployment of AI, particularly frontier models.
A world of many AI superintelligences is preferable to a world with only one AI superintelligence.
In their current level of sophistication, LLMs like ChatGPT do not appear convincingly worrisome—it's what they imply will come next
To mitigate AI existential risks we must also research how, and prevent that, AI's can influence and manipulate humans to do their bidding.
AI will create capacity in the labour market as it takes on easier repetitive tasks. This will should work with not against working reform
We need policy provisions for the design and methods by which AI is developed to ensure it is safe and not harmful or breaking human rights
The pace of AI development should be dictated by the public, not companies
Everyone should list their preference for maintaining their individuality as we become increasingly connected to AI and each other.
Data assets must be made more widely accessible to ensure AI can be widely developed (democratised); rather than power concentration by few.
We should encourage nation-states to regulate AIs as if they were as risky as nuclear technology
We need policy provisions for the design and methods by which AI is developed to ensure it is safe and to prevent market fragmentation
All AI programmes must be coded to self-identity as AI and be accompanied by detection software.
There is no such thing as safe open source ai. Any safety measures or bias mitigation can be reverse engineered.
The only way to police the development and use of AI is by using AI itself.
The development of AI companions is net beneficial to humanity, and should correspondingly not be banned.
My biggest worry is what entities can be trusted with controlling such powerful technology, especially given the interests of Zuck, Musk etc
Successfully aligned AI will use many schools of moral philosophy, not just one.
Predicting as far into the future as possible is critical for existential safety as it allows earlier detection and mitigation of threats.
With the unlimited potential for AI, there has to be a back up business continuity plan to cater for circumstances when AI could go wrong.
I am nervous and pessimistic about the current direction of AI development.
The issues we are discussing with AI are present in already established areas inc. statistics, quantitative research, and machine learning
AI regulation will be contingent on better regulation of mass data collection.
Western arguments that we are in an AI race against China and therefore must innovate quickly are ill-considered
More attention should be given to risks in psychological exploitation of consumers and civilians by AI developers and users.
I think that, on the whole, the West is more advanced and is accelerating faster in AI development, compared to China
Like most technologies that are powerful but dangerous if used incorrectly, users should share responsibility with designers for AI safety.
At some point we must consider consciousness/sentience and when AI might be "awake", potentially deserving ethical rights & considerations
We have reached a point where technology is evolving much faster than humanity and human societies can handle
We should talk about how OpenAI is interfering with non-profit efforts and prevent it somehow
Commandment 3.	Retain control over AI governance beyond 2030
Local CSOs need long term, predictable funding for capacity and consultation to ensure global majority views are meaningfully represented
AI companions should not be used as a replacement strategy for real human contact in our fight against loneliness and isolation.
We should discourage any use of AI to generate statements that look like facts.
We must solve for a sustainable, adaptive, & effective global coordination mechanism—an arms race for AI supremacy cannot be allowed
Setup permanent on-going support for AI Safety Summits as virtual monthly global conferences supported by a debating platform eg Telepresent
Artificial general intelligence (AGI) should make easier life easier but we should aim to have a human-in-the-loop controlling AI.
A business imperative (i.e., profits, growth) must not be the driving force of AI innovation—look where that got us with social media
Pace of AI development should be dictated by the public but realistically it will be AI companies because of exponential pace of change.
Use of publicly available data to train AI is inequitable, and will require copyright reform to address.
Values used in training AIs, like those in Anthropic's Constitutional AI, should be voted on by a global electorate.
Is AI really the future or is something too overhyped??
Is it helpful to think of AI as an 'is' or as an 'are', the multiplicity or singularity of reference reinforcing community or not?
It is naive to expect that an arms race for AI supremacy should not be allowed. It is already happening at an accelerating pace.
I propose AI should be folded into a global-scale Open Knowledge Initiative, similar to Open Science, but broader in scope.
Command 10.	Create a Global Welfare State to mitigate the challenges posed by the turbulent civilisational transition.
We are unlikely to ever agree on global AI regulation due to cultural differences, and should discuss the impact of AI regulation boundaries
How might we incentivize AI for common goods (e.g., better democracy, less pollution, improved education) rather than merely cost-efficiency
The existence of capable AI means increasing the concentration of wealth: accelerating internet driven disintermediation (fewer middlemen)
In a manner similar to companies we should accept that AIs of sufficient capability deserve rights and can own assets (incorporation).
Truly deliberative and participatory forms of democratic governance require a plurality of processes, all open to discussion and change
Regulators must establish minimum standards of explainability ('black box' problem) and ban the release of new AI tools that do not comply.
There are cases in which AI should not be implemented or used due to significant systemic or cultural discrimination (e.g., recidivism risk)
Small-world networks provide a precise way of describing how to balance between distribution and regulation of AI.
The international community is untrustworthy and has demonstrable biases that should not be carried forward to AI
We should make a Global Welfare State to mitigate the challenges posed by the turbulent civilisational transition.
We need cooperative-ownership of AI models: the missing piece is not regulation, but ownership.
Commandment 1.	Adjust the world governance to a civilisational shift
As we expand AI, we collectively redefine what counts as knowledge in our societies: a huge step that needs much more careful reflection
Commandment  2.	Undertake a comprehensive deep and fast reform of democracy
We need to discuss how politics , government and law will be affected by AI. I am a former Member of Parliament.
Commandment 5.Create Global AI Control Agency (GAICA) to control AI development process not just reguation. Invite China & others.
How might AI be used to enable global coordination solutions, enabling major states/institutions to cooperate against other crises & x-risks
We need supper fast global Program of developing friendly Superintelligence by liberal democracies based on kind of 10 Commandments - follow
Command 8.Create Global AI Governance Agency (GAIGA) under the mandate of the G7 to oversee both GAIRA and the GAICA Consortium
AI corporations don't need local consent for large environmental projects; their expertise suffices.
People fear what they do not understand. Developing a better comprehensive narrative on how AI decisions are made is a must.
We should focus on mitigating the known recurrences of AI incidents from new entrants, products, and services(racial bias in face rec tech)
We need a de facto World Government initiated by G7, incorporating members from NATO, EU, the European Political Community and OECD
AI is not only a new type of tecnhology. Most importnatly it is first ever a NEW TYPE OF INTELLIGENCE.
We should prioritize investments in AI technologies that benefit the wealthiest in society, as they will trickle down to benefit everyone
It's too late to think about AI replacing us or not, either we evolve or become extinct.
We should create a Global AI Regulation Authority (GAIRA) to regulate the use of AI by transforming Global AI Partnership (GPAI)
We need to create one Superintelligence Programme managed by One-AI JV company to streamline AI control capabilities.
We should undertake a comprehensive deep and fast reform of democracy
How will AI and its spin-offs affect politics and law? Our current systems are not sufficient. I am a former Member of Parliament.
Should Phonons be part of future AI, this should be widely known
We should use AI to enhance the abilities of humans, creating a class of individuals better equipped to survive climate change.
Overreliance on AI may exacerbate a less skilled & less engaged citizenry; an agenda should ask how AI might supplement, but not replace us?
We should prioritize the development of AI technologies even if it results in significant job losses in traditional sectors.
Commandment 7.Create one Superintelligence Programme managed by One-AI JV company to streamline AI control capabilities.
Should Phonons be part of future AI, will this be useful, or generally known.
Command 9.Create a de facto World Government initiated by G7, incorporating members from NATO, EU, the European Political Community and OECD
We need to create Global AI Control Agency (GAICA) to control AI development process not just reguation. Invite China & others.
We are unlikely to ever agree on global AI regulation since we do not have World Government - competition is king!
Governments should implement strict surveillance using AI to enforce regulations, even at the cost of individual privacy.
While global standards are ideal, it's crucial to have localized AI regulations that respect cultural and societal norms.
We should allow AI to control and manage entire cities to optimize environmental sustainability, even if it reduces human control & agency.
Human populations should be controlled and managed by AI systems to ensure sustainable resource use and environmental conservation.
We should Create Global AI Governance Agency (GAIGA) under the mandate of the G7 to oversee both GAIRA and the GAICA Consortium
AI should assist in creating cities with clean air and less noise pollution.
We should use AI-supported deliberative democracy to renew/update the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as an underlying constitution
AI should help kids learn about the environment in fun and interactive ways.
The benefits and risks of AI systems should be equitably distributed, not concentrated among a few groups.
Ethical philosophers who understand AI (e.g. Carissa Veliz) are a key part of the conversation

We need to adjust world governance towards a civilisational shift
It is important that AI governance does not lead to confrontation between states, AI should be above politics.

If we had a visual language for explaining AI systems to stakeholders, they would have more power to effect positive change.
AI does not pose substantially different challenges to those we've already addressed in the case of other technologies or science
Caution and care, not speed, should guide the development and deployment of transformative AI applications.

AI can help us design products that last longer and reduce the culture of throwaway consumerism.

AI technologies should strive to be as energy-efficient as possible to mitigate their environmental impact.
AI can enhance environmental impact assessments and scenarios for sustainable policymaking.
We should be compensated for the use of our data in AI systems.
AI development should adhere to a universally accepted ethical framework that prioritizes human well-being and environmental sustainability.
AI should respect all living things, not just how they can be used for human benefit.
AI researchers and developers have an ethical responsibility to consider the environmental impacts of their work.
AI can help achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals, if developed responsibly and inclusively.
We should challenge statements like "This is inevitable".

AI is the way forward for global cooperation in international law.

AI systems should promote justice, empowerment, and environmental stewardship, not just efficiency and profit.

An appreciation of multiple ethical perspectives should be mandatory for all AI leaders.
Matching renewable energy supply and demand using AI grid management will enable decarbonization.
AI can help optimize energy grids, reducing waste and carbon emissions.
The government and AI companies are responsible for poor outcomes of AI, not AI itself.
AI should be used judiciously in accordance with principles of justice, fairness and human dignity.
We should prioritize the use of AI in creating affordable and green housing solutions.

AI should guide us to care for the health of our whole planet, not just human societies.

AI can drive optimization but also increased consumption - sustainable values should guide its design.

AI should assist in fostering a community spirit, encouraging people to work together for a cleaner and greener future.
